title: Heartbreaking Netflix documentary Tell Me Who I Am has thought-provoking story behind it
text:

Tell Me Who I Am is not always comfortable viewing but it comes from a place of emotional truth.

The critically-acclaimed documentary has arrived on Netflix and tells the story of twin brother Alex and Marcus Lewis and how one huge decision changed the course of both of their lives.

After being left in a three-month coma in 1982 following a motorcycle accident, 18-year-old Alex Lewis awoke with no memories apart from the recognition of his twin brother, Marcus.

Now placed in a position of care for his brother, Marcus made a difficult decision: to omit the truth of their abusive childhood at the hands of their mother and to re-imagine Alex's life into something idealised and far from reality.

"My life is not real," says Alex in the documentary. "My life is the one you gave me."

The documentary forces the two brothers to confront this secret and the gap between reality and Marcus' lies in very intimate scenes.

But what was it that led to this story being tackled?

(Image: NETFLIX)

Director Ed Perkins told TIME : "It played out like a psychological thriller. And yet it was true.

"I was fascinated by the themes of brotherhood, the blurring of fact and fiction, memory and the question of who we are if we lose our memory."

Alex Lewis was involved in a motorcycle incident in 1982 at the age of 18 that left him only remembering his name, where he was and his brother, Marcus.

Relying on his twin brother for guidance on everything, with Marcus helping him to understand their own family dynamics in comparison to what the media and culture tell him is normal.

(Image: NETFLIX)

However, as time passes, Alex begins to see that the dynamics are not normal: Alex and Marcus live in a shed but are forbidden to enter the main house, their mother is in denial, and their father is a cold figure.

The truth became much clearer for Alex following the death of their mother when Alex came across a photograph in her belongings of the brothers as young boys, their faces cut off and their bodies naked from the neck down.

It was then that Marcus confirmed they were abused in their childhoods to him but didn't tell him anymore.

On his mother's death, Marcus says in the film: "I felt nothing. I didn't feel any guilt for feeling nothing. I didn't feel sad, I didn't feel relieved, I just felt nothing."

(Image: NETFLIX)

Marcus' decision to keep the details from his brother was - from his perspective - a means of protecting his brother from the trauma and also repressing his own.

The film forced the pair to confront the lies in emotional scenes in the documentary, with Marcus finally being honest with Alex and "giving his brother what he really needed."

While Alex revealed how he resented the silence on what happened in the past that came from Marcus, in return, Marcus revealed how they had been abused by their own mother and "passed around" amongst her acquaintances.

(Image: NETFLIX)

After so much tragedy and hardship, have the pair found the closure they craved?

On where the brothers are now, Perkins also revealed to TIME that the brothers "live incredible and emotionally rich lives. They’re amazing fathers and husbands. It’s very inspiring for me to see people who have gone through more than you’d wish on anybody and yet resolutely refuse to be defined as victims. I really hope audiences are left with a feeling of hopefulness."

Tell Me Who I Am is available now on Netflix.

description: Tell Me Who I Am is an emotional portrait of two brothers and is currently available on Netflix
